ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .

The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.

Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

Instructor: Alark Saxena  The broad knowledge of Alark Saxena proved very useful in the discussions held toward the end of each class session. His ability to play the devil's advocate as well manifested his comprehensive understanding of the different topics that comprise climate change.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This is the toughest eval. i've had to do- or at least is the really the only one that i truly care about.Bailis has potential to be the best teacher at FES--he learns everyone's name, somehow, he cares about the material he teaches, his lectures are well structured and his powerpoints are professional. He is kind and his time for students. He has all the skills.But I don't know about the model of the course that Bailis has chosen. A three hour lecture for 50 students is a challenge for any teacher, and I'm not sure its working for this class. Bowers sucks as a room-we should be right up in Bailis' face and forced to interact with his material. Laptops should be strongly discouraged. I wish the course could be capped at 20 for the intimacy that bailis' work deserves. But he's teaching broad concepts and many people should take the class.I encourage Bailis to consider how to make his class more accessible...and to consider how to incentivize paying attention in lecture more.
With a class titled "Climate Change," I was expecting more from the professor.
too much information to grasp but very useful class

Question 12:Professor Bailis was a fantastic teacher. He seems to be really invested in students' learning, and always made an effort to facilitate greater discussions and more questioning. One of my favorite professors.
This was an excellent class and exposed us to a wide range of important issues related to climate change. It provides a good starting point for us to dig further into any of the topics.
Professor Bailis is fantastic. I hope to take more classes with him in the future.
The professor and the teaching fellow were very approachable and accessible for this class. We got feedback on our reflections each week before the class.

This course was hurt by its size, time slot, and classroom. These aspects make a huge difference. With half the students in a smaller room (Bowers is not an appropriate classroom for any subject) and a better time slot, the class could have been excellent. No courses should only have one class meeting a week and Tuesday afternoon is probably the worst time slot for most students.
Q-4. the instruction was too fast for me to understand. moreover, it was difficult to make out what the instructor was speaking.

I thought this class was fantastic. It put together so many aspects of climate change into one space.As did most of the students, I am more familiar with sections of the course than other sections. I thought the professor did a great job of giving tangible peaks into many different regions of the climate change issue so that students who specialize in one area are now (at least vaguely) familiar with many areas of research.One point of criticism, however, is that the Mitigation part did not come across as well as the Impacts or Adaptation sections. Perhaps it is because my interests lay with Impacts/Adaptation and not as much with Mitigation or because it was just that time of the semester, but I thought it was not as engaging a section as the other two were. Which is to say that it was still incredibly well thought-out and presented. (This comment may be a note more about my own interests, but I thought I'd include it in case others mentioned similar comments.)

I thought this class was fantastic. It put together so many aspects of climate change into one space. As did most of the students, I am more familiar with some sections of the course than other sections. I thought the professor did a great job of giving tangible peaks into many different regions of the climate change issue so that students who specialize in one area are now (at least vaguely) familiar with many areas of research.One point of criticism, however, is that the Mitigation part did not come across as well as the Impacts or Adaptation sections. Perhaps it is because my interests lay with Impacts/Adaptation and not as much with Mitigation or because it was just that time of the semester, but I thought it was not as engaging a section as the other two were. Which is to say that it was still incredibly well thought-out and presented. (This comment may be a note more about my own interests, but I thought I'd include it in case others mentioned similar comments.)

This course offers a very thorough overview of climate change adaptation and mitigation concepts and developments. It will be really helpful for anyone interested in a career in fields related to climate change.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Sections on energy, disaster risk reduction, adaptation. Love the weekly response -- kept me honest on the readings, and interested for the second half of class. very good way to keep people engaged.
The format of our class time together -- lecture paired with discussion.
learning critical background on climate science and policy.
The course provided a great overview of concepts in climate change ranging from policy to adaptation. Bailis delivers concise and engaging lectures.
the opportunity to write a policy memo on anything you wanted.
Writing weekly responses and group discussions
At least one session in class was allotted for a critical aspect of climate change.

I appreciated the in-depth lectures on various aspects of climate change. Equal attention was given to adaptation and mitigation. I also enjoyed the freedom to explore any topic of interest in the adaptation memo and final paper assignments.

The information in the course is very relevant to anyone interested in climate change. The readings were particularly interesting and helpful, and I thought the policy memo and final paper assignments were well designed and struck the right balance between structure and freedom.
The best aspect of this class were the conversations after the lectures.
Group discussions were really helpful.
the discussions with the class were very well structured and i gained a lot from listening and discussing various perspectives on the same topic
The breadth of the material

The exposure to a broad range of topics related to climate change. I think the breadth of the syllabus is the course's strength. Students have an opportunity to dive deep into two topics of their choice through their adaptation memos and final papers.
The readings and reading responses were the best aspects. I would have loved more feedback from Alark and Prof. Bailis and assume the class size limited their ability to focus on individual students.
In-class group discussions
current situation of climate change and updates
The lectures were great. They carried the audience throughout and were well-presented.
The Impacts and Adaptation sections.

Both the readings and discussions were very helpful. The weekly assignment helped me to keep with the readings and get the most out of the in-class discussions and lectures. In particular, I found preparing for and facilitating the in-class discussion to be very useful. I have not had much previous experience facilitating a class, so this was a great experience, and I learned the material for that week the best by far.

It's range of topics, showing the threads of climate change in so many aspects of science, policy, technology, and humanities. The breadth was helpful especially for putting the conversation in a global context.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Rob's lectures could have been more exciting. Towards the end of the semester, it seemed like he was less interested in the class. Even interesting topics became a bit dull.It would have been great to hear more of the prof's personal opinions on the subject, or his research in biofuels. Anything to get below the surface, get into things below the UN level. I'm much more interested in science, state policy, and case studies than I am in UNFCC stuff, so I found the constant return to the international framework to be frustrating.I realize the class needs to cover a lot, so it's hard to dive in more. I'd suggest skipping or severely cutting the portion on climate science -- this part most people know already, or they can read about ahead of time. Or maybe the class could be solely on adaptation. It just felt really general, and it was hard to debate these topics in the second part of class without feeling a bit silly, given that we had only done a handful of readings on them.
I think this class would be better if it were smaller, allowing for more interactions between Bailis and his students.
Format of big lecture.
Discussion sections got off to a rocky start, but improved later in the semester as students gained knowledge and sessions became more activity-centric.

the lectures are dry and the group discussions are not engaging enough.furthermore, if we are expected to write reading responses each week, we deserve more feedback than a one-line response without a grade.
Screen some information which i dont think will be an easy task given the nature of climate change
Some topics needed more in-depth discussion than others. Attempting to treat them more or less equally was detrimental to those climate change related topics that needed more attention.

I wish there would have been more time dedicated to teaching the science behind climate change itself. Only 90 minutes on the first day of class was dedicated to the reasons why climate is changing.I personally did not get much value out of the class discussions. I would have preferred to have longer lectures and less discussion because the class seemed just too big to allow for any meaningful conversation.

As engaged and enthusiastic as he is, the professor is simply not a clear or engaging lecturer at this point. Particularly as a 3 hour, afternoon lecture this made it difficult for students to remain alert and engaged themselves. Also, I would suggest splitting this course up into 2 or 3 courses. As things were, we just scratched the surface of all topics we covered. My impression was that most students in the class had at least some exposure to climate change issues, and at our pace most probably learned very little that was new to them.
I think this course would serve better as two 1.5 hour classes, rather than as one 3 hour lecture. The class could be set up in a very similar way (half lecture/half discussion).

the policy paper was very fun to write but the final paper was not structured. on the one hand this is good because it allows for flexibility but many of us were unclear on what was the objective of the paper.. i think that in the future providing guidelines on the objectives of the paper would be helpful. or continuing with the policy paper framework and expanding on that would be great. maybe with more critical analysis of existing literature..
I would have preferred if the class was a seminar with fewer students.
The discussion sessions were sometimes not as useful as they could have been. Perhaps more structure might help.
The course needed more student engagement during lectures. A smaller class in a better room would have helped solve this problem.
Reading materials
reading materials have to be reduced.

The discussions were lacking. I am not sure if this is because it was the second half of a three-hour class, the fault of discussion leaders, or the size of the discussion groups. I would re-consider how discussions are constructed and seriously consider curtailing the discussion leaders' ability to "be creative" with their discussion format. I found that the "creative" discussions were more often than not a cover-up because the leaders thought the class hadn't throughly read the readings enough to participate. The "creative" discussions, therefore, keep the discussion/games in the abstract and vague level, where even those who did not do the reading could fully voice their general opinions. Rather, I'd have liked to have had an in-depth discussion about the specifics of the readings.

The discussions were lacking. I am not sure if this is because it was the second half of a three-hour class, the fault of discussion leaders, or the size of the discussion groups. I would re-consider how discussions are constructed and seriously consider curtailing the discussion leaders' ability to "be creative" with their discussion format. I found that the "creative" discussions were more often than not a cover-up because the leaders thought the class hadn't thoroughly read the readings enough to participate. The "creative" discussions, therefore, keep the discussion/games in the abstract and vague level, where even those who did not do the reading could fully voice their general opinions. Rather, I'd have liked to have had an in-depth discussion about the specifics of the readings.

This course covered a lot of ground, and the final assignment was an opportunity to explore a topic of interest in greater depth. Unfortunately, there was not much in-class support for developing our paper topics. I think that mandatory 1 or 2 assignment(s) to prepare for the paper, in addition to or in lieu of the weekly readings, would have been very helpful. I think that a bibliography assignment and/or an introduction to Yale's resources and tools for research would have given me a better start on conducting research for the final paper. Also, it would have been helpful to have a mandatory 1-2 page write-up to outline my ideas for a paper topic, after I had started the research (and to catalyze that process). That scoping paper could then be used to facilitate an in-class peer-review or review by the instructor and TA. The optional 1-2 paragraph write-up was useful, but could have been improved with any of these suggestions, or an in-class component.Another area for improvement is the length and density of the weekly readings. It often took me over 7 hours to complete the readings, and I often had to skim some of the readings in the interest of time. Therefore, I did not get as much out of the readings as I would have from thoroughly reading fewer readings each week.
I think the course could be improved by having fewer slides and more discussion and conversation on all the slides.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: It was great!
less role playing (too unrealistic) and more engagement with specific people and their readings.
Very relevant to me

Discussion sections were interesting because there was a variety of formats, but it might be helpful to have somewhat of a similar structure class-to-class (either in the types of questions or format used).

Yes, the students who handled the discussion after the presentation by the instructor of the general topic for the session helped to give more in-depth treatment of a particular area. However I feel that we will have benefited from a separate session entirely devoted to discussions that help reinforce the lecture rather than just the arrangement of having a discussion in small groups at the end of the lecture.
excellent!
The class discussions were effective at fleshing out the course material. Again, smaller groups would have improved the discussions sessions.
Perfect
it was a good relationship because we were given topic to choose and discuss in the class.
See my answer for Q. 15.
The discussions worked well to complement the lectures, not duplicate them.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: alark was a great teaching fellow
Alark had a great attitude, and was always accessible and extremely knowledgeable.
Excellent facilitator, source of knowledge about the class content. Good feedback from the weekly commentaries.
Alark was an amazing TF. He has a lot of knowledge on the topic and is able to engage us in a way that encourages new ideas. it was great working with him!
he was accessible anytime and ready to help. grading was ok.

I received responses to my weekly reading response write-ups. I appreciated the effort that the TA put into these, and I found them very helpful for clarifying points in the readings, or for offering a different angle or perspective from my own, which helped me think more deeply about the issues covered in class.I think the TA's lecture style can be improved with further practice in teaching and lecturing. Overall, his perspective in the discussions was valuable and often different than the other perspectives shared. His experience in climate change adaptation and disaster risk reduction enriched the discussions.
Instructor: Alark Saxena  Alark was great. Responses to our weekly responses much appreciated. Great knowledge of UN processes and of course DRR stuff.
Instructor: Alark Saxena  Alark was very responsive and well-organized.
Instructor: Alark Saxena  He's a baller. Very smart. very considerate of others.only weakness is he has too much on his plate!
Instructor: Alark Saxena  Given his background, he has a clear understanding of the concepts which made my life easier

Instructor: Alark Saxena  I've already mentioned his strengths. I will have preferred if he was more assertive in class beyond what he already showed. Although the constraints may have also been due to how the course was organized.
Instructor: Alark Saxena  Alark was very helpful and provided great feedback on weekly assignments.

Instructor: Alark Saxena  Strengths: a passion for the subject material, involvement in the topics of every class (in fact would participate in the discussions along with the students)Suggestion for improvement: could be a little more organized
Instructor: Alark Saxena  Alark was fantastic, very knowledgeable and hard-working.

Instructor: Alark Saxena  Alark was great. His lecture was well thought out and he was ever helpful within the course itself. My only point of gentle criticism is that he might want to more closely consider punctuation, grammar, and capitalization in his emails.
Instructor: Alark Saxena  Alark was really insightful and passionate about the subject, which helped. However, he was so busy with his PhD work that he was sometimes hard to track down.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: My interest is in energy and also urban land use issues, so it was pretty well related. But the international level was not very relevant, because UN/NGO work is not what I'm looking for.
Climate change fits into everyone's overall program at FES.
i'm interested in climate change.
I will be working for the environment body of the Royal Government of Bhutan. One of the mandates include climate change. So this course is very relevant for me and my work

Climate change is a very broad topic that affects other issues that are themselves broad. Issues such as biodiversity conservation and forest degradation are topics that are by themselves broad. However they also form part of the issue of climate change so the linkages between theses issues are better elucidated upon through the course.
I am interested in clean energy solutions to climate change. Hence an understanding of the impacts of climate change and potential mitigation and adaptation technologies is important to me.
my masters thesis is on climate change science so this class is very much aligned with my research work
It fits very well as I am focused on climate change.

This is an excellent course for FES students, as climate change is the environmental crisis of our times and this course provides a good overview of all topics related to climate change. Rob is an excellent teacher: he's incredibly knowledgeable about the smallest details of each topic, and keyed in to all the latest developments in the climate world. Additionally, he does an amazing job of linking all topics together.

Climate change is a subject interwoven to all environmental work for the foreseeable future. I am personally vested in climate change research and intend to incorporate my understanding of climate impacts into my career.

Gives understanding of how climate change science has evolved until now and it is complex and complicated. Because of my interest in adaptation and mitigation aspects of climate change, I was able to master the key concepts from technical to policy implementations.

my quest for knowing climate change grew when i increasingly began to realize that weather pattens are changing dramatically. i wanted to learn how climate change happens and how humans can adapt to the changing climate.
My research is focused on climate change.
I am researching climate change.
It was good to take this in my first semester of the MEM program because it will inform the other classes that I take related to climate change adaptation and mitigation.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Climate change will be the biggest issue of our generation.
Good roster of other students whose interests aligned with my own.
Climate change is expected to have broad-ranging impacts on land use dynamics, and is of general interest.
interested in climate change.
Answer under Question 20
My research involves REDD+ so a step back and understanding the broad context of climate change is relevant in being able to write about my chosen research topic.
See above.

Climate change is touted as the biggest challenge facing the environmental field. I wanted to make sure that I had a solid base of knowledge regarding climate change as climate change may influence any and all of the topics I ultimately study.
to broaden my understanding of the climate change debate
Because I'm specializing in climate change.
The course syllabus was very interesting to me, and I wanted to take a class with this professor.
Personal and profession interest. See above.
I wanted to equip myself with technical and policy instruments for a comprehensive understanding of the needs of people and the environment to abate the effects of climate change.
my interest in knowing about climate change and how it affects globally.
My research is focused on climate change, and I heard that the Professor was good.
I am researching climate change and heard the professor was good.

I'm interested in a career in climate change adaptation and consulting. I sought to deepen my knowledge in climate change adaptation and learn about concepts and practices in climate change mitigation.
To gain a broad understanding of the disciplines and dialogues around the climate change issue.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.
Yes, I feel much more conversant in climate change topics and the issues of translating science to policy.
no
They did. I found all the classes and discussion sessions interesting and informative
Yes, the course sufficiently addressed my expectations.
Not really. As mentioned above, I felt we grazed the surface of the adaptation and mitigation issues so that I did not come away with as much new knowledge as I would have liked.
This class is primarily a knowledge based class, and yes, the class met my expectations.
yes
Yes
Yes, absolutely!
Yes. More class time could be dedicated to debating climate science--a practice that may prove useful for environmentalists.
Pretty much but I will need a specific adaptation and mitigation class.
yes, although learning was too much time consuming. but i think the subject itself is vast and requires a lot of time.
Above and beyond.
Above and beyond.

Yes. However, I wish I had devoted more time to the final assignment and completed research on a topic that was more relevant to my career interests.Further exploration of careers in climate change policy would have been useful. More guest speakers could help to lend different perspectives and experience to the class.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Too many views within a short time

The topic was something the members of group sufficiently had knowledge of, given their different backgrounds that had to do with the topic. Thus it wasn't an alien concept although not everyone in class was acquainted with it.Given the brief preparation, I believe an opportunity to be more creative will have been helpful if there was more time or had the group prepared earlier than a week before the discussion.
The advantages of group work in this class were bringing people together with different backgrounds and expertise. This made a for a productive class discussion.
it was great...i worked with two students to organize a discussion for the class.. again, it was useful to see how many varied perspectives there are on a topic.
I enjoyed having a small workgroup for the conversation facilitation.
learned knowledge from one another but people who can speak a lot seem to dominate the group and push the points.

Working in a group to plan and facilitate discussion was a great experience. The main advantages were the creativity that everyone brought to planning the facilitation as well as the problem-solving capacity of the group.The main disadvantage was that there were so many great ideas offered, but we had to pick one and execute it in a limited amount of time.
I thought that the small group discussions were the most helpful part, and where most of the learning took place.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do the readings in depth and ask critical questions during lecture.
Take a class with Bailis for sure...think about yourself as a student and whether 3 hour lectures work for your learning style.
It is a sometimes challenging course with a bulk of reading, but if you have an interest in climate change I think you will find it to be rewarding.
meet with rob and alark to receive feedback on your performance. otherwise you won't receive it.
Anyone should take this course. Climate change is real and happening. Learning about is, i believe, is the first important step towards addressing the issue
Be prepared for a general discussion of topics that comprise climate change and not an in-depth discussion of a single topic. Be also prepared for a big class.

This is a relatively low-workload coarse, with short weekly reading responses, one short mid-term paper, and a longer end of term paper. The papers are a great opportunity to explore areas of climate change that might contribute to a broader research project that you're working on.
Good overall refresher on climate change issues, and a good course to interact with other students.

If climate change is your focus, this is likely a useful review course, and the readings and assignments are useful. The same goes for if you have no exposure to climate change. If however you have decent understanding of climate change and it is not your area of focus, I would think twice about taking this course.
take your time digesting the readings, you will gain more from the lectures
Take it!
Shop the course and see if it appeals to you. Consider the size of the class, the classroom, and time slot in your decision.
Please do take the class!
i would advice them to take the course because this course teaches all about climate change.
Read the readings.
Read all the readings.
Start the final paper early, and take advantage of the instructor's and TA's office hours and/or email responsiveness. The more you put into the research paper, the more you will get out of it.
